topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Flexible Control Plane Installation

body.p: As you can see in the overview of the documentation for 1.0, HPE Helion Openstack Flexible Control Plane (FCP) allows you to deploy the control plane in a virtual environment, reducing the control plane footprint to just three servers for proof of concept, evaluation, and exploration of HPE Helion Openstack features.
body.note: As of HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1.1, FCP is in an experimental phase and we do not recommend you use FCP in your production environment. We recommend that you test FCP in your test environment, for small-scale clouds of up to eight compute nodes.
body.p: For additional information about FCP, contact the HPE Helion Support Center.
The overview covered the prerequisites. Now we will walk through the installation.

section.title: Before You Begin
section.p: Before you can install Helion OpenStack using the FCP approach, you will need to:

ul.li: Review prerequisites and configure the infrastructure accordingly

li.p: The installer will create a bridge on each host and a port for the external device will be added to the bridge. The installer will also move the IP address of the external device to the bridge device. This creates a baremetal network through which the virtual machines will communicate with each other and with the real baremetal systems.
If the system running the installer and seed VM does not use the external device name eth0, then determine the device name before running the next step and

codeblock.codeph: $ export BRIDGE_INTERFACE=<devicename> For example: $ export BRIDGE_INTERFACE=em1 or $ export BRIDGE_INTERFACE=eth5

li.p: In the same manner, establish the value of BRIDGE_INTERFACE for each remote host (see below).
Set up the remote hosts. You must set up each remote host identified in your vm-plan file.

a. Use an existing user or create a new user on each remote host to run the virtual machines. The user must have sufficient privileges to launch virtual machines using libvirt, for example, as a member of the 'libvirtd' group.
This user is denoted <kvmuser> below and the host is denoted <hvmhost>.

section.title: After the reboot of the compute node, new FIPs associated to the instance are not accessible
section.p: After updating the cloud, any new FIP being allocated to and associated with an existing or new VM is not accessible.
Currently, the issue can be resolved by deleting the link being added where it is giving an error.

section.title: After the reboot of compute nodes, the instance goes into error state
section.p: After the reboot of compute nodes which have instances running, two issues are noticed:
Issue 1

codeblock.codeph: error: Failed to start domain instance-0000020d error: unsupported configuration: Domain requires KVM, but it is not available.

section.p: Check that virtualization is enabled in the host BIOS and that host configuration is set up to load the KVM modules.
Issue 2

codeblock.codeph: error: failed to connect to the hypervisor error: no valid connection error: Failed to connect socket to '/var/run/libvirt/libvirt-sock': No such file or directory.

section.p: Issue 1: Manual steps to recover
If there is no output, issue the following commands:

codeblock.codeph: modprobe -v kvm modprobe -v kvm_intel service libvirt-bin restart

section.p: Issue 2: Manual steps to recover

section.title: A few VMs with two interfaces (pvt and svc) lost network plumbing on compute node (post update)
section.p: After updating, the VM guest is not accessible on its SVC interface.
No Resolution

section.title: Environment may be unstable upon rebooting of overcloud controllers
section.p: Environment may be unstable for some time when overcloud controllers are rebooted.
On the overcloud controller reboot scenario the cloud takes some time to stabilize.
If overcloud controllers are rebooted, you must wait for some time for the cloud to become stable. Verify basic cloud functionality before proceeding further.

section.title: If the KVM environment is rebooted, the instances in the spawned state cannot be reached via ping
section.p: In the case of an entire KVM environment reboot, previously spawned instances may not be reachable via the ping command.
Hard reboot the spawned instance from the Horizon dashboard to make it reachable.

section.title: A seed cloud host has been rebooted but the VMs hosting the control plane did not start automatically
section.p: A seed cloud host has been rebooted but the VMs hosting the control plane did not start automatically.
The seed cloud host responsible for hosting the seed node has been rebooted. This requires manually restarting the VMs.

p.b: Restart the VMs on the seed's KVM host

li.p: Recover the seed by running the appropriate hp_ced_host_manager.sh command with the --boot-seed argument.

For example: SEED_NTP_SERVER=12.12.12.12 bash -x ~root/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/scripts/hp_ced_host_manager.sh --boot-seed For example, use the same hp_ced_host_manager.sh used during installation but substitute '--create-seed'.
After the seed has booted, ensure that networking works correctly by logging into the seed's IP address, for example, 192.0.2.1.
Once the seed is booted and working as expected, use virsh commands to start the other VMs.
For example:

codeblock.codeph:
virsh start baremetal_0
virsh start baremetal_3

p.b: Restart the VMs on a KVM host not running the seed

li.p: Use the virsh command to start the VMs.
For example:

codeblock.codeph:
virsh start baremetal_1
virsh start baremetal_4

li.p: Verify that the networking works by logging into all nodes after they have been booted.
For more information on networking issues, see Troubleshooting.

section.title: The seed cloud host cannot be reached after it is rebooted
section.p: After the seed cloud host is rebooted, the networking setup does not persist and the seed cloud host cannot be reached.
The networking setup on the FCP seed cloud host must be set up in a particular way. Otherwise, the seed cloud host cannot be reached after it is rebooted.
Change the network configuration in the interfaces file to a configuration that supports persisting the network setup.

li.p: Define the primary interface in its own configuration file in etc/network/interfaces.d/.
Alternatively, define the primary interface in /etc/network/interfaces and format the file so it has a line separator between each interface definition. (See man files for an example.)

ul.li: Ensure that every interface is defined in its on ifcfg-<interface> file within /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/
